ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual section once a week as well, though these sometimes also were lectures.
Each class, we'd spend about half the time watching a pre-recorded lecture and the other half discussing and working on example problems.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Solid overview of Distributed Morphology, a leading theory of morphosyntax. Experience writing and editing formal linguistics papers.

I learned a lot about the Distributed Morphology model of morphology -- how words are constructed, how they're represented in a syntax tree, etc. I also got better at reading and writing linguistics papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was listed as having prerequisites of Syntax I and Phonology I, but these were then waved, which was a huge mistake. There was a large range of skills and backgrounds in the class, which led to it being taught to the lowest common denominator, leaving more experienced students somewhat bored. Otherwise quite interesting, good range of topics considered and feedback to student interest.

The material is very interested and the course is cohesive. It does move quickly at times, but I also didn't have as strong a background in syntax as some of the people in the class, so that's probably one reason it felt quick.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using pre-recorded lectures worked very well -- it ensured that they didn't go over time (except for the rare instance of technical difficulty) and that we'd be able to discuss afterwards.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, if you have already taken a syntax course, otherwise don't bother.

If you're interested in the field, absolutely! The class does move very quickly, so if you're not motivated to keep up, it could be a struggle. It may also help to have taken syntax ii, but you can get by without as long as you're willing to put in some extra work.
